Violation_Type: Failure to meet criteria for Convention Refugee or person in need of protection
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed persecution due to imputed political activities and family association; alleged torture by Indian police
Evidence_Used: Applicant's testimony, claims of torture and persecution
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient evidence linking claim to Convention grounds; lack of proof that state protection was unavailable
Credibility_Assessment: RPD found the applicant's claims not sufficiently substantiated
Decision_Outcome: RPD determined applicant was not a Convention Refugee nor in need of protection
Relief_Sought: Recognition as a Convention Refugee or person in need of protection
Legal_Standard_Applied: Definition of Convention Refugee under s. 96 IRPA; Person in need of protection under s. 97 IRPA
Decision_Rationale: The RPD's conclusion was reasonable based on lack of sufficient evidence connecting the harm to a Convention ground and availability of state protection in India

Violation_Type: Failure to meet burden of proof for refugee status
Lack of nexus to Convention grounds
Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), Section 96 and 97
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed persecution by uncle and NDC officials in Ghana after leaving political party; reported attack to police but could not identify assailants; cited political opinion as basis for fear
Claimant_Status: Applicant for refugee protection in Canada
Residency_Compliance: Not applicable – claimant was outside country of nationality seeking protection
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review of Refugee Protection Division decision
Evidence_Used: Documentary evidence on Ghana's police reforms
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient evidence that state was unable or unwilling to protect
No identification of attackers limited police response
Lack of evidence linking harm to Convention grounds
Credibility_Assessment: Board found applicant did not sufficiently demonstrate state protection failure or persecution nexus
Decision_Outcome: Refugee claim dismissed
Relief_Sought: Recognition as a refugee in Canada
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of Refugee Protection Division decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: Well-founded fear of persecution
Burden of proof on claimant
Presumption of state protection
Decision_Rationale: Applicant failed to rebut presumption of state protection; insufficient evidence of state inability or unwillingness to act; no established nexus between alleged harm and Convention grounds

Aggravating_Factors: Inadequate state protection for domestic violence victims
Risk_Assessment: High risk due to lack of effective state protection
Evidence_Sufficiency: Insufficient according to RPD, but court found contradictory evidence was ignored
Evidence_Credibility: Partially accepted, but selective reliance undermined credibility assessment
Credibility_Assessment: RPD's assessment found unreasonable due to failure to address contradictions

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refugee claim determination
Crimes.Procedural_Fairness_Issue: Alleged lack of opportunity to present evidence on state protection
Crimes.Evidence_Disclosure_Status: Subjective belief not supported by documentary evidence

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Availability of state protection in country of origin
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's fear deemed subjective and uncorroborated
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Lack of objective evidence supporting police targeting

Crimes.Violation_Type: Inability to access state protection due to employer coercion
Crimes.Governing_Law: Canadian immigration law and international refugee principles
Crimes.Application_Facts: Claimant feared persecution by employer with alleged state complicity
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Insufficient evidence to prove state protection unavailability

Crimes.Crime_Name: Acts contrary to the purposes and principles of the United Nations
Risk_Factor: Perceived complicity in crimes by the Peruvian army
Nature_of_Acts: Alleged involvement in acts contrary to UN principles
Key_Evidence_Issue: Lack of evidence establishing personal involvement
Credibility_Assessment: Testimony deemed not credible
Standard_of_Proof: Serious reasons must exist for considering involvement
Legal_Provision: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, S.C. 2001, c. 27

Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Outcome: Decision overturned, remanded for new hearing
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged involvement in war crimes during service
Decision_Outcome: Partially allowed judicial review
Legal_Provision: Article 1F(a) and (c) of the Refugee Convention
Risk_Nature: Fear of persecution due to reporting drug trafficking

Risk_Factor: Perceived complicity in crimes by the Peruvian army
Nature_of_Acts: Alleged complicity in crimes against humanity
Key_Evidence_Issue: No specific findings linking applicant to crimes
Credibility_Assessment: Credibility undermined by implausibility
Credibility_Factors: Lack of detailed or corroborating evidence
Standard_of_Proof: Serious reasons to believe involvement required

Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Outcome: Board's decision incorrect, remanded for new hearing
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged complicity in crimes against humanity
Decision_Outcome: Partially allowed judicial review
Jurisdiction: Federal Court jurisdiction over immigration matters
Risk_Factor: Personal risk due to reporting internal corruption
Risk_Nature: Threats from Peruvian army after reporting drug trafficking
Victim_Basis: Whistleblower targeted for exposing criminal activity

Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant remained in Canada beyond the authorized period of stay
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Jurisdiction of IRB over refugee claim
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Subjective fear dismissed due to delay
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Patent unreasonableness for credibility, reasonableness simpliciter for state protection
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Long delay in claiming refugee status; insufficient evidence of state protection failure

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to comply with removal order
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant remained in Canada after refugee claim rejection and issuance of removal order
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Assessment of ongoing risk despite removal order
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Board failed to consider available evidence on state protection
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Fear not adequately assessed; evidence ignored
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review allowed; decision set aside
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Risk of gender-based persecution and state protection
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Patent unreasonableness for credibility, reasonableness for state protection
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Board erred in dismissing fear and underestimating state protection gaps in Jamaica

Crimes.Crime_Name: Domestic abuse (non-specific charges without more details, potential charges could include Assault, Criminal Harassment, Threatening Death under the Criminal Code of Canada)
Crimes.Mitigating_Factors: Not applicable in context of victimization
Crimes.Prior_Criminality: Perpetrator had history of abusive behavior
Crimes.Criminality_Severity: High – credible threats and physical harm
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: Ongoing risk upon return to country of origin
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Non-state actor violence with inadequate state protection
Crimes.Targeted_Victimization: Yes – based on gender and relationship
Evidence_Type: Expert reports on domestic violence in Jamaica
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Fear was subjectively genuine and objectively reasonable
Crimes.Sentencing_Issue: Not applicable – crime occurred abroad and not prosecuted in Canada
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Criminal Code of Canada (potential charges: Assault, Criminal Harassment, Threatening Death)

Legal_Issue: Whether the Board erred in concluding applicants were not Convention refugees or persons in need of protection
Credibility_Assessment: Principal applicant’s inconsistent statements undermined credibility
Evidence_Type: Credible evidence of state protection in Peru, evidence regarding Shining Path threats and DINCOTE persecution
Legal_Provision: Lack of state protection, absence of valid internal flight alternative (IFA) under IRPA
Basis_of_Claim: Alleged persecution by Shining Path and Peruvian anti-terrorist police
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Availability of state protection in Peru and reasonable internal flight alternative in Lima
Application_Factor: Credibility, state protection, internal flight alternative
Decision_Outcome: Applicants not recognized as refugees or persons in need of protection
Authority: Immigration and Refugee Board, Federal Court

Application_Facts: Applicant faced persecution by state agents (OJI) in Costa Rica; seeking help from these agents would have increased danger; lawyer attempted to involve Ombudsman without success
Procedural_Issue: RPD's determination that applicant did not adequately seek state protection
Evidence_Used: Evidence of persecution by state agents, attempt to engage Ombudsman
Decision_Outcome: RPD’s conclusion found unreasonable
Relief_Sought: Recognition as a refugee based on lack of state protection
Remedy_Sought: Redetermination by a new RPD panel
Legal_Standard_Applied: Presumption of state protection can be rebutted with clear and convincing evidence of state's inability to protect
Decision_Rationale: Seeking protection from persecuting state agents would have increased risk; efforts through Ombudsman failed; RPD's finding was unreasonable under the circumstances
Authority_Responsible: Immigration and Refugee Board (IRB), Refugee Protection Division (RPD)

Application_Facts: The Board excluded the applicant based on his AL membership and linked police abuses to him without direct evidence.
Procedural_Issue: Exclusion issue raised mid-hearing without prior notice, breaching procedural fairness
Evidence_Used: Membership in AL, alleged association with police abuses
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of direct evidence linking applicant to abuses
Decision_Outcome: Excluded under Article 1F(a)
Outcome: Judicial review allowed, case remanded for rehearing
Legal_Standard_Applied: Serious reasons to consider commission of crimes against humanity
Decision_Rationale: Insufficient evidence and procedural unfairness in applying Article 1F(a) exclusion

Dispute_Type: Refugee claim exclusion under international law
Legal_Issue: Whether Article 1F(a) exclusion was properly applied without sufficient evidence or procedural fairness
Evidence_Assessment: No direct link between applicant’s role and human rights abuses; role as youth leader not equated to control over police
Decision_Outcome: Excluded from refugee protection under Article 1F(a)
Burden_of_Proof: On the Board to show serious reasons for considering commission of crimes
Credibility_Factor: Applicant's claims of persecution in Bangladesh
Legal_Rule: Complicity requires personal and knowing participation in crimes against humanity
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged complicity in human rights abuses by political party
Outcome_on_Merits: Board’s decision found flawed due to lack of evidence and fairness
Key_Evidence_Considered: Applicant's leadership role in political party, reports of police abuses
Outcome: Judicial review granted, matter referred for rehearing

Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: IRPA s.106, Refugee Protection Division Rules s.7
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant provided a birth certificate and Panamanian driver's license with inconsistencies in names; explanations deemed implausible by the Board.
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Provided documents with inconsistent information and failed to offer credible explanation
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Failure to meet burden of proof in identity establishment
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Inconsistent documentation and lack of supporting evidence
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Explanations found implausible by the Board
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Board concluded applicant failed to establish identity
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Successful refugee claim based on established identity
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Burden of proof on claimant to establish identity
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Insufficient and inconsistent documentation; failure to provide reasonable explanation for discrepancies

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to establish identity under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: IRPA s.106, Refugee Protection Division Rules s.7
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant provided limited documentation (birth certificate, driver’s license) with name discrepancies; did not take sufficient steps to obtain additional documents.
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Failure to comply with documentation requirements
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of credible identity documents or plausible explanation for absence
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Explanations considered implausible; insufficient efforts to retrieve documents
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Board found applicant did not meet burden of proof for identity
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Recognition as refugee with verified identity
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Claimant must provide acceptable identity documents or reasonable explanation
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Documentation insufficient and uncorroborated; explanations not credible

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Authenticity of identity documents in immigration context
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether applicant established identity with credible documentation
Crimes.Governing_Law: IRPA Section 106, Refugee Protection Division Rules Section 7
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Documents questioned due to inconsistencies and lack of corroboration
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Board reasonably doubted authenticity of submitted documents
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Inability to explain discrepancies in documents
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Claimants must provide acceptable identity documentation or reasonable explanation
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Applicant failed to prove identity through credible means
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act and related rules
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Certification of question and allowance of judicial review
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review dismissed, no question certified
Crimes.Legal_Provision: IRPA Section 106, Refugee Protection Division Rules Section 7

Governing_Law: Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms
Application_Facts: Plaintiff claimed persecution; tribunal praised candour but found fabrication; ignored post-arrival evidence; misinterpreted obligation to claim in first safe country
Residency_Compliance: Complied with residency requirements upon arrival
Misrepresentation_Element: Alleged fabrication of persecution claims despite positive demeanor findings
Procedural_Issue: Failure to provide clear and unambiguous reasons for credibility determination
Jurisdictional_Issue: Proper jurisdiction under IRB and Federal Court review powers
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Tribunal ignored relevant post-arrival evidence supporting credibility
Credibility_Assessment: Inconsistent assessment: praised candour yet concluded fabrication without clear justification
Decision_Outcome: Refugee claim rejected based on credibility
Legal_Standard_Applied: Clear and unambiguous reasons for administrative decisions
Reasonableness standard
Decision_Rationale: Ambiguous and contradictory reasoning undermined fairness and transparency of decision
Authority_Responsible: Refugee Division of the Immigration and Refugee Board

Application_Facts: Applicant claims PRRA officer ignored relevant evidence about Sri Lanka's conditions; officer relied on general improvements in Sri Lanka’s conditions
Procedural_Issue: Selective use of country reports and omission of contrary evidence alleged
Evidence_Used: Country reports used selectively by PRRA officer
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Omission of evidence contrary to the officer's conclusions
Decision_Outcome: PRRA application denied
Relief_Sought: Successful PRRA application, reversal of removal risk assessment
Legal_Standard_Applied: Patent unreasonableness
Decision_Rationale: Officer's decision did not significantly misrepresent risk; cited evidence does not alter core claim of risk upon return

Application_Facts: Applicant is a Haitian businessman who claimed a personalized risk of violence due to perceived wealth in Haiti
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Risk found to be generalized rather than personalized
Credibility_Assessment: Risk not deemed personal; applicant's claim considered part of generalized violence in Haiti
Decision_Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed
Legal_Standard_Applied: Personalized risk under Section 97(1)(b)(ii) of IRPA
Decision_Rationale: The risk faced by the applicant was determined to be generalized across Haiti and not specific to the individual or subgroup beyond the general population

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failing to comply with removal order
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), section related to removal orders
Crimes.Application_Facts: Samaroo failed to report for removal despite knowing the order; ignored legal obligation after negative immigration decision
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Yes, prior misrepresentations contributed to inadmissibility
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Minister raised misconduct shortly before hearing
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court jurisdiction over judicial review applications
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Record of false claims, visa application fraud, and non-compliance with removal
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: None noted; evidence of non-compliance was clear
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Samaroo found not credible due to history of deception and non-compliance
Crimes.Outcome: Application dismissed on grounds of unclean hands
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Judicial review of refusal of permanent residence
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Overturning of removal order and grant of permanent residence
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Discretionary power to dismiss based on unclean hands
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Repeated abuse of immigration system outweighed family unification interests

Crimes.Crime_Name: Making false statements to obtain immigration visa
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of immigration decision
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Unclean hands due to fraudulent conduct in visa application
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Samaroo deemed lacking credibility due to intentional falsehoods
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Visa application records, refugee claim documents, removal order history
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Intentional deception to gain immigration benefit
Crimes.Application_Error: Material misrepresentation in visa and refugee application
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Balance of integrity of immigration system vs. individual rights
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Discretion to dismiss for unclean hands
Crimes.Application_Factor: History of abuse and lack of remorse
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Yes, false statements in visa and refugee applications

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review involving misconduct
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Dismissal of application due to unclean hands and systemic abuse
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant found to have repeatedly abused the system
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Pattern of false claims, visa fraud, and non-compliance
Crimes.Legal_Provision: IRPA provisions on misrepresentation and removal compliance
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Pattern of deceit and failure to comply with removal
Crimes.Application_Error: Multiple instances of fraud and non-compliance
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Integrity of administrative process vs. equitable considerations
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Court’s discretion to dismiss for unclean hands
Crimes.Application_Factor: Lack of good faith participation in immigration process
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Yes, supported by false documentation and claims

Crimes.Crime_Name: Serious criminality under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Application_Facts: Respondent pleaded guilty to cocaine trafficking, sentenced to three years with 30 months pre-sentence custody credited, leaving six months to serve.
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Permanent Resident or foreign national subject to inadmissibility
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: IAD excluded pre-sentence custody from 'term of imprisonment' under s. 64(2) IRPA
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Interpretation of 'term of imprisonment' under federal immigration law
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Sentencing record, plea of guilt, credit for pre-sentence custody
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: IAD failed to consider pre-sentence custody as part of sentence
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: IAD decision set aside, case referred for redetermination
Crimes.Outcome: Loss of appeal rights due to serious criminality confirmed
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Overturn IAD decision on interpretation of term of imprisonment
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Interpretation of s. 64(2) IRPA in light of s. 719(3) Criminal Code
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Pre-sentence custody forms part of the term of imprisonment under IRPA

Crimes.Crime_Name: Possession of cocaine for the purposes of trafficking
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Criminal sentencing and immigration consequences
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether pre-sentence custody counts toward 'term of imprisonment' under IRPA s. 64(2)
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Court assessed sentencing judge's credit for 30 months pre-sentence custody
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: IAD decision overturned, case remitted for rehearing
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On immigration authorities to establish inadmissibility
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Pre-sentence custody is part of the sentence under s. 719(3) Criminal Code and included in 'term of imprisonment' under IRPA
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Erroneous interpretation of 'term of imprisonment' by IAD
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Respondent found to meet serious criminality threshold under IRPA
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Guilty plea, sentencing transcript, credit for pre-sentence custody
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Intersection of criminal sentencing and immigration law
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Pleaded guilty to possession for the purpose of trafficking
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Certified question answered, IAD decision set aside
Crimes.Outcome: Appeal rights lost due to serious criminality; deportation order likely enforceable
Crimes.Authority: Immigration Appeal Division (IAD), Federal Court on judicial review

Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 87(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations (IRPR) - Procedural Fairness
Application_Facts: Applicant's permanent residence application was refused based on alleged fraudulent employment certificates and credibility concerns; officer relied on unclear CAIPS notes and contacted wrong Johnson Controls office; Tower letter misinterpreted despite evidence of full-time employment
Misrepresentation_Element: Alleged fraudulent employment certificates, but no proven intentional misrepresentation
Procedural_Issue: Failure to provide applicant with opportunity to respond to credibility concerns
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Clerical error in verification (wrong office contacted)
Credibility_Assessment: Negative credibility finding based on flawed verification and lack of applicant response opportunity
Decision_Outcome: Visa refusal upheld initially by officer
Remedy_Sought: Redetermination of application by different officer after procedural fairness is observed
Legal_Standard_Applied: Procedural fairness under administrative law
Decision_Rationale: Visa officer violated procedural fairness by not informing applicant of credibility concerns and denying right to respond before making adverse decision
Authority_Responsible: Visa Officer at Canadian visa office

Application_Facts: Judge reviewed documents and stated satisfaction with residency criteria without detailed analysis
Residency_Compliance: Assessed as compliant, but without sufficient reasoning
Procedural_Issue: Failure to provide clear and detailed reasons for decision
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of reference to specific evidence or analysis of documents
Decision_Outcome: Citizenship application approved initially
Remedy_Sought: Reconsideration by a different Citizenship Judge
Legal_Standard_Applied: Statutory duty to provide adequate reasons
Decision_Rationale: Reasons were too brief and failed to demonstrate application of correct legal test or consideration of all facts

Victim_Status: Applicants were victims of repeated criminal victimization due to family wealth
Targeted_Victimization: No evidence of personal targeting beyond financial motive
Targeted_Individual: Family as a whole due to wealth
Evidence_Type: Testimony and documentation of prior incidents
Evidence_Credibility: Assessed as speculative regarding personal targeting
Credibility_Assessment: Reasonable assessment by the Board

Victim_Status: Applicants were victims of repeated criminal victimization due to family wealth
Targeted_Victimization: No evidence of personal targeting beyond financial motive
Targeted_Individual: Family as a whole due to wealth
Evidence_Type: Testimony and documentation of prior incidents
Evidence_Credibility: Assessed as speculative regarding personal targeting
Credibility_Assessment: Reasonable assessment by the Board

Victim_Status: Applicants were victims of kidnapping and extortion due to family wealth
Targeted_Victimization: No evidence of personal targeting beyond financial motive
Targeted_Individual: Family as a whole due to wealth
Evidence_Type: Testimony and documentation of prior incidents
Evidence_Credibility: Assessed as speculative regarding personal targeting
Credibility_Assessment: Reasonable assessment by the Board

Violation_Type: Refugee claim denial based on lack of particularized risk
Application_Facts: Applicants experienced repeated criminal victimization in Mexico
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review of Refugee Protection Division decision
Evidence_Used: Incident reports, testimony, country condition evidence
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of evidence showing personal targeting
Credibility_Assessment: Board reasonably assessed credibility
Decision_Outcome: Denial of refugee protection
Remedy_Sought: Overturning of Refugee Protection Division's decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: Particularized risk under section 97 of IRPA
Authority_Responsible: Refugee Protection Division, Federal Court on judicial review

Victim_Status: Applicants were victims of extortion and kidnapping threats due to family wealth
Targeted_Victimization: No evidence of personal targeting beyond financial motive
Targeted_Individual: Family as a whole due to wealth
Evidence_Credibility: Assessed as speculative regarding personal targeting
Credibility_Assessment: Reasonable assessment by the Board

Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant overstayed visa, suffered severe injuries, undergoing psychotherapy and physical therapy, had pending humanitarian and compassionate (H&C) application, sought deferral of removal on medical and humanitarian grounds
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Enforcement Officer failed to properly assess medical evidence and made unreasonable factual inferences
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Officer did not adequately consider submitted medical evidence
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Deferral of removal based on medical and humanitarian grounds
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Removal must be executed as soon as reasonably practicable under IRPA s.48
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Officer made patently unreasonable findings regarding treatment availability in Fiji and failed to properly assess ongoing medical needs
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Enforcement Officer, Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada (IRCC)

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to comply with removal order
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant remained in Canada after issuance of removal order due to medical conditions and pending H&C application; requested deferral of removal
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Subject to removal order with pending H&C claim
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant due to failure to depart following removal order
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Officer failed to thoroughly consider medical evidence and mischaracterized treatment prospects in country of removal (Fiji)
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient consideration of medical evidence and lack of inquiry into healthcare accessibility in Fiji
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Request for deferral of removal denied
Crimes.Outcome: Decision set aside on judicial review; remitted for reconsideration by a different officer
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Deferral of removal based on health and humanitarian considerations
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Reconsideration of deferral request by a new enforcement officer
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: IRPA s.48 – removal to be carried out as soon as reasonably practicable; limited discretion to defer based on exceptional circumstances
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Officer's conclusions about medical treatment availability in Fiji were unreasonable and based on inadequate assessment
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Enforcement Officer, Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada (IRCC)

Violation_Type: Failure to meet criteria for Convention refugee status
Application_Facts: Perger family claimed persecution in Hungary due to Roma ethnicity; attack on female applicant deemed isolated; six-year delay in leaving Hungary unexplained
Residency_Compliance: Not applicable – claimants left Hungary after alleged persecution
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review of Immigration and Refugee Board decision
Evidence_Used: Details of attack on female applicant, timeline of events, country conditions in Hungary
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Unexplained six-year delay in leaving Hungary, lack of evidence showing ongoing risk or pattern of persecution
Credibility_Assessment: Fear of persecution not found to be objectively well-founded
Decision_Outcome: Refugee status denied
Relief_Sought: Recognition as Convention refugees, reversal of IRB decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: Well-founded fear of persecution based on race, religion, nationality, social group, or political opinion
Decision_Rationale: Attack was isolated and not atrocious or appalling; no compelling reasons arising from previous persecution under subsection 2(3); delay in fleeing undermined objective basis for fear
Authority_Responsible: Immigration and Refugee Board, Federal Court

Crimes.Governing_Law: Federal Court Act, s. 18.2; Immigration Regulations
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant overstayed her visa, married, and had a child in Canada. Claims irreparable harm due to family separation if required to leave.
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Seeking stay of departure order to challenge adjudicator's refusal to sever inquiry from spouse's case
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Whether court can grant stay under s. 18.2 of Federal Court Act
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: No proof of grave harm (e.g., threat to life, safety, or medical evidence of psychological harm)
Crimes.Outcome: Applicant must leave Canada to avoid deportation
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Stay of execution of departure order
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Irreparable harm, serious issue, balance of convenience (implied)
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Court has jurisdiction but no irreparable harm demonstrated; voluntary departure avoids adverse consequences

Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant overstayed visa; spouse faced misrepresentation charges; joint inquiry resulted in departure order. Claims harm from family separation and inability to return without Minister’s Permit.
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Temporary resident (visa overstayer, linked to misrepresented application)
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Alleged indirect involvement via spouse’s misrepresentation; no direct finding against applicant
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Judicial review of departure order; request for stay pending review
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Court jurisdiction to stay departure order under s. 18.2
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: No medical or psychological evidence supporting irreparable harm; no proof of inability to reunite abroad
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Demonstration of irreparable harm required for stay
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Jurisdiction exists, but irreparable harm not proven; voluntary departure mitigates consequences

Crimes.Crime_Name: Inadmissibility under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant joined LTTE at age 13, served until 21, claimed forced membership but panel found voluntary involvement
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Applicant seeking to overturn inadmissibility finding
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Judicial review for reasonableness of panel's decision
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Credible evidence of LTTE’s terrorist activities and applicant’s prolonged membership
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of evidence supporting claim of forced detention
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Panel found applicant's claims about forced membership not credible
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Voluntary membership in terrorist organization established by credible evidence; age did not negate responsibility

Crimes.Crime_Name: Engaging in or instigating subversion by force of a government
Crimes.National_Security_Danger: Threat posed by membership in LTTE
Crimes.Threat_Assessment: LTTE engaged in subversive and violent acts against state authority
Crimes.Risk_Factor: Prolonged involvement with an armed separatist group
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Credible evidence supporting LTTE’s subversive nature and applicant’s role
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Issue: Applicant’s claim of forced membership vs. evidence of continued voluntary involvement
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Documentary and testimonial evidence on LTTE activities and applicant’s service
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant’s claims of coercion not supported by evidence
Crimes.Credibility_Factors: Duration of membership, lack of escape attempts, adult continuation of service
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Interpretation of 'membership' and applicability of exceptions

Crimes.National_Security_Danger: Threat from association with designated terrorist entity
Crimes.Threat_Assessment: LTTE is a listed terrorist organization; membership poses security risk
Crimes.Risk_Factor: Seven years of active involvement including adulthood
Crimes.Nature_of_Acts: Military training, combat support, organizational loyalty
Crimes.Target_Entity: Civilian and military targets in Sri Lanka
Crimes.Admission_or_Involvement: Joined at 13, served until 21, fled to Canada
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Strong evidence of LTTE’s terrorist designation and applicant’s sustained role
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Issue: Whether membership was voluntary despite young age at entry
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Official designations, witness testimony, applicant’s own statements
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant failed to prove duress or inability to leave
Crimes.Credibility_Factors: Length of service, absence of corroborating evidence for coercion
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Scope of 'membership' and applicability of s. 34(2) exemptions

Crimes.National_Security_Danger: Direct and indirect participation in terrorist acts through organizational membership
Crimes.Threat_Assessment: LTTE responsible for suicide bombings, assassinations, and attacks on civilians
Crimes.Risk_Factor: Active member during period of known terrorist operations
Crimes.Nature_of_Acts: Supporting and participating in armed insurgency involving terrorist tactics
Crimes.Admission_or_Involvement: Member from age 13 to 21; participated in LTTE activities
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Well-documented pattern of LTTE terrorism and applicant’s affiliation
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Issue: Voluntariness of continued involvement into adulthood
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Public records, expert reports, immigration hearing transcripts
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant’s defense of coercion not substantiated
Crimes.Credibility_Factors: Failure to defect when possible, extended duration of service
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Interpretation of engagement in terrorism via organizational membership
Crimes.Consequences_of_Action: Denial of entry and protection in Canada

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to provide necessaries of life (negligence claim dismissed)
Application_Facts: Inmate injured during an assault and claimed negligence due to delayed medical attention.
Procedural_Issue: Trial focused on whether the defendant breached duty of care; causation deferred to second phase.
Decision_Outcome: Action dismissed with costs to the defendant.
Outcome: No breach of duty of care found.
Legal_Standard_Applied: The Crown is vicariously liable for negligence if an officer, acting within employment scope, fails to meet the standard of care expected of a reasonable person.
Decision_Rationale: No evidence that corrections officers acted below the standard of care. The plaintiff’s condition was not visibly obvious, and multiple checks were conducted without signs of distress.

Application_Facts: Inmate assault leading to Bastarache's injury and subsequent negligence claim against prison staff.
Procedural_Issue: Trial focused on whether prison staff breached duty of care; bifurcated trial separated liability and damages.
Decision_Outcome: Action dismissed with costs to defendant.
Outcome: No breach of duty of care occurred.
Legal_Standard_Applied: Prison authorities owe a duty of care to inmates, requiring reasonable measures to ensure their health and safety.
Decision_Rationale: Bastarache was injured but concealed it, locking his cell. Officers conducted regular checks without noticing distress. No evidence shows officers acted below the standard of care.

Decision_Outcome: Action dismissed with costs fixed at $1,500 payable by plaintiff to defendant.
Criminal_Activity: Inmate assault leading to severe injury and subsequent negligence claim against prison officials.
Outcome: No breach of duty occurred as officers acted reasonably given the circumstances.
Basis_for_Decision: Bastarache was injured but concealed it, locking his cell after refusing medical attention. Officers conducted regular checks without noticing issues. Blanchard’s claim of alerting officers was deemed unreliable.
Legal_Framework: Prison authorities owe a duty of care to inmates, requiring reasonable measures to ensure health and safety. Liability arises if actions fall below the standard of a reasonably prudent person.

Credibility_Assessment: Blanchard’s claim of alerting officers was deemed unreliable.
Legal_Provision: Prison authorities owe a duty of care to inmates, requiring reasonable measures to ensure health and safety. Liability arises if acts or omissions fall below the standard of a reasonably prudent person.

Crimes.Violation_Type: Unauthorized work and re-entry with expired permit

Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of valid documentation supporting temporary intent
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Found not credible due to inconsistent statements
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Barua lacked genuine intent to comply with temporary resident conditions

Crimes.Application_Factor: Admission of intent to stay permanently without proper status
Crimes.Document_Fraud: No document forgery, but false representation of status

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Credibility assessment based on testimonial inconsistencies
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Did the Board err in rejecting the applicants' identity based on minor inconsistencies in testimonial evidence?

Crimes.Application_Factor: Reliance on oral testimony due to lack of documentation
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Remanded for re-determination by a different Board member
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Use of fraudulent German passports to enter Canada

Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), section 97
Governing_Law: Regulations related to refugee protection and determination
Application_Facts: Applicants claimed persecution as Roma and threats from Michaela's boyfriend; Board found boyfriend's threat unreliable, state protection adequate, and no distinct evidence warranting separate section 97 analysis
Misrepresentation_Element: Inconsistencies and omissions in applicants' statements
Procedural_Issue: Need for separate section 97 analysis assessed and rejected
Evidence_Used: Board's assessment of credibility and state protection
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of reliable evidence supporting boyfriend's threat
Credibility_Assessment: Board found applicants' claims lacking in credibility due to inconsistencies and omissions
Decision_Outcome: Refugee claim dismissed
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed; Board's decision upheld
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of Refugee Protection Division's decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: Well-founded fear of persecution
Risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment
Decision_Rationale: Credibility findings reasonable, state protection available, no need for separate section 97 analysis due to lack of distinct evidence

Application_Facts: Mr. El Falah reported conflicting absence periods (391 vs. 351 days); insufficient proof of Canadian residence during claimed periods
Residency_Compliance: Failed to demonstrate physical presence of at least 1095 days over four years
Misrepresentation_Element: Inconsistent reporting of absences indicating potential misrepresentation
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Conflicting absence reports, lack of supporting documentation for residency
Credibility_Assessment: Citizenship Judge found applicant's evidence inconsistent and unconvincing
Decision_Outcome: Application rejected
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of citizenship application rejection
Remedy_Sought: Overturn of decision and approval of citizenship application
Legal_Standard_Applied: Physical presence requirement under paragraph 5(1)(c)
Decision_Rationale: Judge reasonably concluded that Mr. El Falah failed to provide sufficient, credible evidence to meet the residency requirement

Governing_Law: Canada's Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Application_Facts: Applicant alleged persecution in Slovakia due to Roma ethnicity and threats from biological family; faced self-representation due to legal counsel issues; inconsistencies in narrative and lack of corroborative evidence were noted.
Misrepresentation_Element: Potential credibility issues due to inconsistencies in narratives and lack of corroboration
Procedural_Issue: Procedural unfairness due to lack of legal representation and inadequate consideration of evidence
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of corroborative evidence, inconsistent narratives
Credibility_Assessment: Credibility findings deemed unreasonable by the court
Decision_Outcome: RPD decision quashed and remanded for reconsideration by a differently constituted panel
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review, annulment of decision, remittal for reconsideration
Legal_Standard_Applied: Credible fear of persecution, inability to access state protection, procedural fairness
Decision_Rationale: Procedural unfairness affected outcome, credibility assessments were unreasonable, state protection analysis lacked sufficient basis

Credibility_Assessment: Unreasonable Findings
Focused on Inconsistencies

Evidence_Type: Complaint allegations, absence of supporting evidence

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Constitutional challenge to administrative action
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Validity of information demand during criminal investigation vs. audit

Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Nature and purpose of MNR's questionnaire and inter-divisional coordination
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Mixed success; further cross-examination and document production ordered

Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Blurred lines between Audit and Investigations divisions
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Under Jarvis, inspection powers cannot be used once purpose shifts to penal liability
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Not finally determined; remitted for further factual inquiry

Crimes.Outcome: Re-attendance for cross-examination and production of documents ordered

Crimes.Authority: Jarvis precedent on separation of audit and investigation functions

Crime_Name: Discrimination based on race, color, national or ethnic origin, and disability
Dispute_Type: Allegation of racial discrimination and harassment in employment
Legal_Issue: Whether the Canadian Human Rights Commission breached its duty of fairness by failing to conduct a thorough investigation
Evidence_Assessment: Investigator failed to explore systemic discrimination claims, made factual errors, overlooked key allegations
Decision_Outcome: Commission's decision set aside due to procedural unfairness
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate procedural unfairness in investigation
Credibility_Factor: Allegations by Mr. Herbert regarding discriminatory treatment during RCMP employment
Legal_Rule: The Commission must ensure investigations are thorough and fair, considering all relevant evidence before dismissing a complaint
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness, with attention to procedural fairness
Grounds_for_Claim: Procedural unfairness, inadequate investigation, failure to address systemic claims
Outcome_on_Merits: Not reached; complaint remitted for reinvestigation
Key_Evidence_Considered: Mr. Herbert’s complaint details, investigator’s report, omissions in investigation
Legal_Framework: Administrative law, human rights law, procedural fairness
Defendant_Response: Commission dismissed complaint under section 44(3)(b) without addressing investigative deficiencies
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence, complaint filings, investigation records
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review, setting aside of dismissal, new investigation
Outcome: Application allowed; matter remitted for reinvestigation by a different investigator
Legal_Provision: Section 44(3)(b) of the Canadian Human Rights Act
Authority: Canadian Human Rights Commission, Federal Court
